perturbation.original_text: MAINTENANCE OF SOLVENCY. This provision applies only to benefits provided through the General Account. If the solvency of the Society becomes impaired, you may be required to make an extra payment. The Board of Directors will determine the amount of any extra payment. It will be based on each member's fair share of the deficiency. You may make the extra payment by an equivalent reduction in benefits or by a payment in cash. If you do not make the extra payment within 60 days from the date we notify you of your share of the deficiency, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest compounded at the rate of 5% per year.
perturbation.changed_text: MAINTENANCE OF SOLVENCY. This provision applies only to benefits provided through the General Account. If the solvency of the Society becomes impaired, you *may not* be required to make an extra payment. The Board of Directors will *not* determine the amount of any extra payment. It will be based on each member's fair share of the deficiency. You *must* make the extra payment by an equivalent reduction in benefits or by a payment in cash. If you do not make the extra payment within 60 days from the date we notify you of your share of the deficiency, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest compounded at the rate of 5% per year.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces ambiguity regarding the policyholder's obligation to make extra payments if the Society's solvency is impaired. Originally, the contract stated that you 'may be required' to make an extra payment and that the Board of Directors 'will determine' the amount. The modified text now states that you '*may not* be required' to make an extra payment and that the Board of Directors '*will not*' determine the amount. It then goes on to say '*must*' make the extra payment. This creates an in-text contradiction because it is uncertain whether the policyholder is obligated to pay. This contradiction directly impacts the 'MAINTENANCE OF SOLVENCY' section, creating uncertainty about the contractual requirements during times of financial instability.

perturbation.original_text: DIVIDENDS. Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is not expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.changed_text: DIVIDENDS. Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend. Since we *do* expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is *not* expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction concerning dividend allocation. Initially, it states that the contract is not expected to contribute to divisible surplus and, therefore, no dividends will be credited. The modified text indicates that the contract is expected to contribute, yet *still* no dividends are expected to be credited. This creates confusion regarding the dividend policy and how it is to be determined. The contradiction directly affects the understanding of the DIVIDENDS section, creating conflicting interpretations on the possibility of dividend allocation under the contract.

perturbation.original_text: ASSIGNMENT The ASSIGNMENT section is amended to include the following: You may transfer ownership of this contract in accordance with our bylaws. Society membership rights and privileges cannot be transferred or assigned.
perturbation.changed_text: ASSIGNMENT The ASSIGNMENT section is amended to include the following: You *cannot* transfer ownership of this contract in accordance with our bylaws. Society membership rights and privileges *can* be transferred or assigned.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a clear contradiction regarding the transferability of the contract and society membership rights. The original text allows the transfer of contract ownership but prohibits the transfer of membership rights. The modified text explicitly prohibits the transfer of contract ownership while simultaneously stating that membership rights can be transferred. This creates ambiguity about whether the contract can be transferred and whether membership benefits are tied to the contract ownership, thus confusing the ASSIGNMENT section. This contradiction affects the overall understanding of ownership and rights associated with the contract.
